awd_titl_txt: Crystallization and glass formation in colloidal-hydrogel suspensions
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Advances in synthetic, experimental and modeling/simulation methodologies have considerably enhanced our understanding of materials. Yet, despite this remarkable progress, many outstanding challenges remain in our quest to understand how the properties of the basic material units or particles determine the properties at the macroscale. This work uses small soft particles to address this question. In particular, the project aims at understanding how single-particle deformability and compressibility affect formation of ordered and disordered solids. The research involves graduate and undergraduate students, and provides materials for enhancing existent soft matter physics courses, both at the theoretical and laboratory-work levels. We also exploit the natural connection between the science we address and food and cooking, to bring the research to the general public; this is achieved by bringing chefs and scientists together and organizing outreach events that include talks and demos by the speakers.

Technical Abstract
This project uses colloidal hydrogels as model soft particles to address (i) the formation of disordered solids and how it depends on the single-particle softness, and (ii) elucidate how size mismatch and polydispersity affect crystallization in soft-particle suspensions.  One focus is the relation between glass formation and jamming, and whether these are distinct mechanisms, and if so, in which way and in what parametric range are they at play, for formation of disorder solids made of colloidal hydrogels. Another focus is to unravel the relation between fragility, which quantifies the way the liquid approaches the glass, and single-particle elasticity. The third focus is to elucidate the mechanism enabling crystallization of polydisperse colloidal-hydrogel suspensions. Ultimately, the overarching goal of this research is to understand and eventually exploit how single-particle softness affects macroscopic behaviour. The techniques employed include 3D-static light scattering, as well as small angle neutron and X-ray scattering, to quantify the structure of the suspension, 3D-dynamic light scattering and rheology, to quantify the dynamics at different time and length scales, and osmosis, to determine the suspension osmotic pressure, an important state function for colloidal systems. The experimental work is complemented with computer simulations and numerical calculations.

por.por_cntn:
Single atoms and molecules come together to make materials with specific properties. Our understanding of how these properties arise from the individual constituents has benefited from using colloidal particles, which can be thought of as large versions of atoms that also jiggle around due to temperature and experience phase transitions from a fluid to a crystal phase or that kinetically arrest in glassy states. In this project, we have explored the role of being a squishy and deformable colloid, much like a sponge, in determining the many-particle behavior of the suspension.

A remarkable manifestation of this single-particle compressibility is the self-healing behavior seen in suspensions comprised of soft particles with a size mismatch. While in most materials such a situation would result in the presence of point defects, which would suppress crystallization, in these suspensions this limitation can be overcome, with the larger particles shrinking to fit in the lattice formed by the smaller ones. We have elucidated that the underlying reason for this behavior is the presence of ions in solution, which can exert sufficient pressure to causes shrinking of the large soft particles enabling the crystallization of the small soft particles without defects.

We have also studied and discovered that the softness of the colloidal particles can further affect the kinetics of crystallization. The softer the particles are, the longer it takes for them to crystallize.

In some instances, when the particle concentration is changed abruptly enough, instead of crystallizing, colloidal suspensions can form disordered solids or glasses. The details of how soft-particle suspensions glassify is still under debate and there is widespread behaviour that has been reported on the subject. We have addressed this issue in this project and found that depending on how soft the particle is, the dynamics of the colloids seem to decouple from what the material structure would dictate. Highly dense liquids have what we call short range order, in that a given atom or molecule is likely to have a shell of neighbours a distance away equal to the atom or molecule diameter. The same is true for dense colloidal liquids. As a result, colloids would spend most of the time located around their neighbours a distance roughly equal to its diameter. Hence, the colloid would be found to slow down at length scales comparable to the particle diameter. We have found that this is not true for sufficiently soft colloids, indicating that particle softness might have unexpected effects and bring about dynamical processes that can alter the way we think about more conventional behavior.

Finally, we have looked inside the soft particles and quantified the internal structure depending on how squeezed the particles are. While in some conditions, the shrinking behaviour is uniform throughout the particle, in other situations, the particles become heterogeneous and exhibit highly dense and highly sparse regions.

In addition to having an impact in the soft condensed matter community, our work might have implications in materials science, as it could aid the development of responsive, tunable and self-healing materials with the right, and perhaps unprecedented, mechanical properties. In addition, the understanding gained in the project might also be relevant for biology, as cells are soft by construction and assemble together to form tissue and biological materials whose properties depend on the rigidity of the constituent building blocks.
